sentence: The red car ran into the blue one which caused it to hit the man
If not for the actions of the red car, the blue car would not have hit the man.
The red car did not brake in time which rammed into the blue car. The force of the red car caused the blue car to pull forward which hit the man.

Well, to me it looked like the blue car drove magically through the red car and then hit the man. I didn't notice the red car doing anything at all, cept having the blue car drive through it. If I have to give blame to anyone, it's gonna have to be the blue car.
Since red car hit the blue one and made it hit the man, it is the red cars fault.
If the red car had not hit the blue car, the accident would not have happened.  It all started with the red car driving into the blue car
The blue left a fair amount of room between himself and the man.  The red car pushed the blue car into the man.
The blue car would never have hit the man if it had not been for the negligence of the red car.
The red car clearly hit the blue car which in turn forced the blue car into the man.
The red car hit the blue car which was not moving so they are to blame.
If the red car hadn't hit the blue car the blue car would not have hit the man.
The red car hit the blue car, which caused the blue car to hit the man.
Red car ran into blue car which in turn caused it to run into the man. Without the red car, the blue car would not have run into the man.
I gave the specific blame that I did because of how the specific events that led to the man being hit by the car unfolded.
your graphic isn't the best, but i took it that the red car ran into the blue car and the force of the impact is what caused the blue car to hit the man
the red car hit the blue car, causing it to hit the man. If the red car wouldn't have hit the blue car, than the man most likely wouldn't have been hit.
The blue car did hit the man but it was because of the red car that this even happened, so the red car is to blame.
The blue car seemed to be a safe distance from the person, and the blue car only hit the person when the red car collided into it.
The blue car was already stationary and would not have hit the man if not for the red car.

The red car hit the blue car and caused it to move into the man. There is no indication of there being anyone in control of the cars so the assumption is that they were autonomous in their movement, in other words, the cars moved themselves somehow (gravity, momentum, etc.)
A reaction from the back-end hit, caused the blue car to hit the man. It was certainly involuntary.

I'm assuming the blue car lost control when the red car hit him and the blue car did not intentionally target the standing man. The red car is ultimately responsible for what happened, but I'm not sure his intent was to hit the blue car, and certainly not to hit the man.
The red car hit the blue car, and the blue care ricocheted and hit the person as a result.
The red car pushed the blue car into the man.
The blue car kept going and didn't stop.
In my personal experience, the person who rearends another car is almost always at fault.
The red car hit the blue car into the man.
The blue car was to blame because every driver should yield to pedestrians
both the cars were stationary to start with, so i am not even sure if there is someone in the blue car
The red car hit the blue car, then cause the blue move to hit the man.
The man would not have been hit by the blue car if the red car had not pushed it into him. I feel it is the red car who is at fault for the blue cars accident.
If the red car hadn't hit the blue car and pushed it into the man the blue car wouldn't have hit him.
The blue car would not have hitthe man if the fed car had not hitthe blue car.
The blue car wouldn't have hit anyone if the red car didn't hit the blue car.
The red car caused the blue car to hit the man.
The blue car could have swerved to avoid hitting the man. That car is to blame for hitting the pedestrian.
The blue car would not have hit the man unless the red car specifically hit the blue car first.
The red car crashed in to the back of the blue car.
both cars were driving at adequate speed, yet the blue one still ended up hitting the man.
the red car hit the blue car which in turn hit the man, but it wasn't the blue car's fault as if the red car didn't hit the blue car the blue car never would have hit the man.
The blue car was unable to react to the red car hitting it so quickly at probably a higher speed. The blue car was also stopped, and only moved and hit the man because it was hit from the back.

Full disclosure, I am an accident reconstructionist with a State Police Agency.  The blue car was, presumably, stopped for the man when the red car hit the blue car.  The red car was either traveling too fast to allow himself to react to the stopped vehicle, or was not paying attention to the roadway.
The blue car was not moving initially.
the red car hit the blue car. That pushed him into the man.
The red car hit the blue car which caused the blue car to run into the man.
The red car hit the blue car and pushed it into the man.
The blue car hit the man, but the blue car was originally fully stopped. The red car collided with the blue car instead of stopping, pushing the blue car into the man.
I blame the red car because the blue car wouldn't have hit the man if it had not been rear-ended by the red car.
It seems the blue car zoomed past the red car and hit the man.
The red car rear ended the blue car forcing it into the man, had the red car been following at a safer distance or paying attention it could have been avoided.
The blue car hit the man. point blank.
the blue car was keeping enough distance from the man but the red car was not cautious enough

I feel that while the blue car is the one that actually hit the man, this would not have happened if the red car had not hit the blue car first. The actions of the red car are clearly to blame in this situation.
The blue car would not have otherwise hit the man. The reason that it did, is because the red car ran into the back of the blue car.
red car hits blue
I think because the red car hit the blue so hard that it made the driver of the blue car lose control and hit the man

Because the red car hit the blue car and caused it to run into the man.

the red car hit the blue car causing it to move forward and hit the man.
The blue car is the one that hit the person. He had plenty of space after passing the red car to stop.

the red car bumped the blue car causing the blue car to hit the man

Because the red car caused the accident, the blue car hitting the man was a continuation of the accident.

The blue car magically drove through the red car and hit the man.

If I am not mistaken, the blue car was to the rear and somehow passed through the red car, thereby proceeding to hit the man. As a result, I don't believe the driver of the red car bears any responsibility for what happened.  The driver of the blue car is entirely responsible.
The red car moved forward hitting the blue car, propelling the blue car into the man.
The blue car would not have hit the man if not being hit by the red car.
The red car hit the blue car causing the blue car to hit the man.
The fault was of the man in the red car.  If he did not hit the blue car, the blue car would not have hit the man

It reminded me of the speeding, tail-gaiting, passing IDIOTS I have to battle all day on the Mount Baker Highway (lots of ski bums and other loafers who don't work for a living), while I'm trying to deliver the mail and avoid being killed. (I was hit twice in the last 16 years while on the route. Doesn't anyone WORK anymore in America?) Even when I lived in Wisconsin (again, delivering the mail), did I ever see anyone, not even Chicago drivers, try to pass TWO cars at once like they do all the time here in Washington state! When you drive 55 mph you're supposed to be 155' behind the car in front of you, not five or 15' feet !!!
The red driver initiated contact due to unsafe driving and is thus liable.
The red car pushed the blue car into the man, the blue car had no control over the situation.

The blue car wasn't moving until the red car collided with it from behind. It was then that the blue car moved forward and hit the man. Without more physical information, it isn't possible to determine what really happened. All I could tell from the 2-D clip is that the blue car didn't move until the red car hit it.
He hit the man...recklessly

The red car is the one that caused the chain reaction. If it hadn't hit the blue car, the blue car wouldn't have hit the man. So, the red car is mostly at fault. But the blue car should have brakes applied firmly and enough distance between it and the man to not hit the man if hit from behind. So, the blue car is also at fault.
the blue car had n control over its actions
the blue car drove straight into him
The Red car is ultimately the cause of the person being hit because of it's failure to stop.  The Blue car was hit into the person.
It appeared that the red car slammed into the blue car, forcing it into the man.
the red car just sat there. the blue car moved and hit the man.

If the car behind me had controlled his vehicle appropriately and stopped before hitting my vehicle my vehicle would have avoided hitting the car in front of me. There for I place the blame for the hole thing on the car that hit the back of my car, just as I place all the blame on the red car here.

It depends upon the situation, and whether the blue car has automatic or manual transmission.  If manual transmission, on a flat level, the driver might have just been resting his/her leg for a moment; the red car might have been drunk, texting or otherwise not paying attention.  It is possible, however, that the blue car with manual transmission should have been hypervigilent of this odd and unlikely scenario, and had his/her leg on the brake, even on level ground, at all times.
